Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Dor Ben-Amotz of Purdue University of Colorado and his graduate and undergraduate student colleagues are studying the way water influences the behavior of substances dissolved in it. Water-mediated interactions play a central role in biological, medicinal, environmental, and materials chemistry, and yet the magnitudes (and in some cases even the signs) of most such interactions have not been experimentally determined. Hydration-shell spectroscopic measurements are combined with theoretical and simulation analysis to quantify the free energy driving forces and the structural changes associated with the water-mediated aggregation of solutes such as dissolved alcohols, salts, gases, carboxylic acids, and surfactants. The quantitative experimental and theoretical studies of water-mediated interactions may advance the understanding of biochemical systems and of self-assembled devices. The research provides training and mentoring opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, as they participate in the project.

Prof. Ben-Amotz and his research group conducts combined Raman spectroscopy with multivariate curve resolution (Raman-MCR) to measure aggregation-induced changes in hydration-shells of aqueous solutes. A new sequential self-modeling curve resolution strategy is used to quantify changes in the concentrations of non-aggregated and aggregated solute species. Random mixing and molecular dynamics simulations, combined with finite lattice and weighted random mixing theoretical analysis strategies are used to separate direct and water-mediated, as well as energetic and entropic, contributions to the aggregation potential of mean force associated with both binary interactions between pairs of solutes and cooperative interactions between multiple solutes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water-mediated interaction play a central role in biological, geological, and environmental processes, many of which involve interactions between water and molecules containing non-polar (oily) and polar (ionic and dipolar) interfacial regions. The structural and energetic interactions between water molecules and such interfaces drive a myriad of molecular binding, recognition, and self-assembly processes. This grant was focused on addressing key open questions regarding the structure of water that surrounds molecules dissolved in liquids such as the streams, lakes, oceans, and biological fluids such as sweat, tears, and blood. This was done by combining Raman scattering with multivariate curve resolution and theoretical modeling studies used to better understand the interactions between oily molecules in water, as well as between salts and oily molecules in water, of relevance to biological self-assembly processes. 


The results of this grant funding have been described in thirteen papers plus one review article. The impact of this work is evidenced in part by the fact that some these publications have already received a significant number of citations in other peer reviewed publications. Other significant publications resulting from this grant pertain to the structure of acidic water, water containing dissolved carbon dioxide, and water containing dissolved methane, each of which are environmentally and/or biologically important. These papers also all address longstanding questions regarding the interactions between these molecules and water. For example, this work has established that the acid (protons) in water is primarily bound to two water molecules. Our studies of carbon dioxide in water have, for the first time, detected its very weak hydrogen bonding interaction to water. Moreover, the studies of methane dissolved in water, which has played an important role in natural gas recovery from solid hydrates under the ocean, have addressed a longstanding question regarding whether water around methane is or is not ice-like. The answer is that it is not, although the water around methane is slightly more ordered the pure water.
